== Who I am ==

I am a sentient loaf of toast named Sultan; I go by kerneltoast on the internet. I joined Canonical as a Kernel Engineer on July 8th, 2019.

I've worked on Linux kernels as a hobby obsessively for the past 8 years, mainly on Android smartphones. I've worked for the State of California churning out !JavaScript and C# (not kernel code, sadly), and for Comma.ai, where I did bring-up work for kernels on Android smartphones and dev boards that were re-purposed to drive cars autonomously.

I've been interested in computers from a young age. I remember excitedly upgrading my dad's laptop to Windows XP the day it came out, though I think these days no one is excited about seeing another Windows update. In 5th grade, I discovered !RuneScape from other kids in my class at my new elementary school. I may have become slightly addicted to !RuneScape, but my motivation to get the game to run well on the aging hardware that was available to me at home eventually led me to Ubuntu.

== My Ubuntu story ==

In 2010, I was complaining to a friend in !RuneScape about overall poor performance on my dad's 2008 Acer netbook rocking an Intel Atom CPU and Windows XP, and he suggested I look into something called Ubuntu. After reading through many guides, I downloaded Ubuntu 10.04 to a flash drive and booted it up on the netbook, and it was magical. Everything had cool orange accents and the performance improvement was night-and-day compared to Windows XP (!RuneScape was smoother too!). This quickly led to my addiction of Ubuntu and trying out all the flavors, as well as breaking some of my family's computers due to botched attempts at creating dual boot installations. I ditched Windows for Ubuntu completely at around this time and haven't looked back since.

=== My involvement ===

I'm a member of the Stable Kernel Team. My usual responsibilities are centered around the life cycle of the stable kernels: fixing them, building them, and testing them. This means that I get to participate in the preparation, packaging, release, and maintenance of Ubuntu's stable kernels. I also review patches coming in from the mailing list as well as patch issues within our kernels. I realize that there are millions of people relying on Ubuntu's kernels in one way or another, and so I do my best to ensure that we produce a stable product. I'd sleep better at night not having upload rights, since it would reduce the scope of how much I could break an OS relied upon by millions of people, but obtaining upload rights is a step I must take to be able to contribute more to the team.
